Back: An unbounded sequence of tuples/events/records generated continuously over time. Example: S = t₁, t₂, t₃, t₄, ...
The time it takes to process a tuple/event, calculated as t_output - t_input. Modern systems achieve latency of a few milliseconds.
The capacity of the system measured as the number of events processed per unit of time.
A directed acyclic graph (DAG) where nodes are operators and edges (vertices) represent data flows between operators.
Operators that process incoming data as soon as it arrives, creating a result for every individual tuple. Examples: filter, transform operators.
Operators that can only produce results after receiving all data tuples. Examples: sum, join, aggregation operators. They require windows to avoid waiting forever.
A fixed-size, non-overlapping window based on count or time. Each event belongs to exactly one window.
An overlapping window that slides over the data stream with configurable size and slide interval. Events can belong to multiple windows.
A window that groups events based on activity gaps or session boundaries. Window closes after a configured timeout with no activity.
The time of the local clock on the machine where the operator processing the stream is being executed.
The time when an event in the stream actually happened, typically embedded as a timestamp in the event data.
A logical clock that informs the system about the current event time. When an operator receives a watermark with time T, no further events with timestamp < T will be received.
Handling events that arrive late or not in chronological order, often caused by network delays or multiple sources with varying delays.

Front: What causes disorder in data streams?
Back: Items from the same source taking different routes, many sources with varying delays, or data sorted on different attributes.
State maintained by operators in stream processing, including list state, union list state, and broadcast state.
State organized as key-value pairs in stream processing, allowing partitioned processing where each key has its own state.
Storage mechanisms for operator state. Options include in-memory (JVM heap) for fast access but limited memory, or disk-based (RocksDB) for slower access but larger capacity.
A processing guarantee where events may be lost but are never processed more than once. No recovery mechanisms for failed events.
A processing guarantee where events may be processed multiple times but are never lost. Achieved through replay after checkpoint.
A processing guarantee where each event is processed exactly once. Requires checkpoints, state consistency through transactional updates or snapshotting, and special sink connectors.
Consistent snapshots of system state taken periodically for recovery purposes. Allow the system to resume from a known good state after failures.
User-triggered checkpoints with additional metadata that enable starting a different application, changing parallelism, or versioning application state.
A distributed checkpointing algorithm that creates consistent snapshots without pausing the entire system, using checkpoint barriers that flow through the data stream.
The process of discarding some data when the system is overloaded to maintain performance and prevent queue buildup. Involves deciding when, where, and how much to shed.

Front: What are the three questions of Load Shedding?
Back: When: constant evaluation of system load. Where: dropping as early as possible to save resources. How much: determining the percentage for random drops or predicate for semantic drops.
Load shedding that chooses what to shed based on Quality of Service (QoS) criteria, dropping the lowest utility tuples first using filters with predicates.
Load shedding that eliminates a random fraction of input, with each incoming tuple having a p% chance of being dropped.

A theorem stating that a distributed system can only guarantee at most 2 of 3 properties: Consistency (all nodes see same data), Availability (all requests get answers), and Partition tolerance (system works during network failures).
All nodes in a distributed system see the same data values at the same time. Used in ACID systems with synchronous replication.
Some nodes may see different data values temporarily, but if updates stop, the system eventually reaches strong consistency. Used in BASE systems with asynchronous replication.
Distribution of database rows across nodes based on selection criteria. Also called sharding.
Distribution of database columns across nodes based on projection. Different attributes of the same relation stored on different nodes.
Combination of horizontal and vertical fragmentation, distributing "projected columns" from "selected rows".
Storing multiple copies of data at different nodes to improve availability, reliability, and performance. Requires consistency management.
A concurrency control protocol with two phases: growing phase (acquire locks) and shrinking phase (release locks). Ensures serializability.
A distributed transaction protocol with prepare phase (coordinator asks participants to vote) and commit/abort phase (execute global decision). Ensures atomicity.
A deadlock occurring across multiple nodes where transactions on different sites wait for each other in a circular pattern.
On-Line Transaction Processing: focuses on short online transactions, current data, high throughput, ACID properties, and operational databases.
On-Line Analytical Processing: focuses on complex queries, historical data, aggregations, read-only operations, and data analysis in data warehouses.
A repository of integrated, subject-oriented, non-volatile, time-variant data designed to support data analysis and decision making.

Front: What are the four characteristics of a Data Warehouse?
Back: Subject-oriented (organized by user perspective), Integrated (consistent naming/formats), Non-volatile (read-only historical), Time-variant (time-series data).
A data warehouse schema design with a central fact table connected to multiple dimension tables in a star-like pattern.
A star schema variant where dimension tables are normalized, reducing redundancy but potentially increasing join complexity.
A schema with multiple fact tables sharing common dimension tables, also called galaxy schema or fact constellation.
The central table in a data warehouse storing quantitative measures/metrics and foreign keys to dimension tables. Typically very large (up to 1 TB).
A table describing attributes of one dimension of a fact table, providing context and descriptive data for analysis. Usually denormalized.
Extract-Transform-Load: the process of extracting data from sources, transforming it (cleaning, formatting, integrating), and loading it into the data warehouse.
An OLAP operation that aggregates data to a higher level of hierarchy, summarizing detailed data.
An OLAP operation that disaggregates data to a lower level of detail, decomposing summarized data.
An OLAP operation that selects one dimension value to create a sub-cube, reducing dimensionality by one.
An OLAP operation that selects multiple dimension values across multiple dimensions to create a sub-cube.
An OLAP operation that rotates the view of data, reorienting the multidimensional perspective.
A smaller, department-specific data warehouse containing a subset of enterprise data focused on specific business needs.
A data lake approach where data is written in raw format and schema is applied when reading/querying the data. Provides flexibility for multiple interpretations.
A traditional database approach where schema is enforced when writing data, ensuring consistency but reducing flexibility.
Integration of multiple heterogeneous databases with a unified global schema, providing transparent access while maintaining local autonomy.
The local schema that a database exposes to the global level in a multi-database system, representing the shared subset of local data.
The integrated view of all databases in a multi-database system, providing a unified conceptual schema for global queries.
An integration pattern where the mediator coordinates queries using the global schema, and wrappers translate between the mediator's interface and local database systems.
The process of finding correspondences between multiple database schemas, identifying equivalent or related elements.
The process of creating a global conceptual schema using correspondences found during schema matching, merging local schemas.
The process of mapping data from local databases to the global schema while preserving semantic consistency.

Front: What are Name Conflicts in schema integration?
Back: Conflicts where different names are used for equivalent entities (synonyms) or the same name is used for different entities (homonyms).

Front: What are Structure Conflicts in schema integration?
Back: Conflicts involving missing attributes, different relationships (one-to-many vs many-to-many), or entity vs attribute representations.
Conflicts where equivalent data is represented differently: different units (Celsius vs Fahrenheit), precision levels, or value sets.
Breaking a global query into subqueries that operate on local databases, the first step in distributed query processing.
Mapping global query fragments to local database queries, translating from global language to local languages.
Data lacking a fixed schema with flexible structure, where elements may have different attributes. Examples: XML, JSON, web pages.
Web content hidden behind search forms, authentication, or dynamic generation that cannot be accessed by standard web crawlers. Estimated at over 500 billion documents.
A program that systematically browses web pages for indexing. Types include incremental (revisit pages), focused (specific topics), and parallel (multiple coordinated crawlers).
An index structure mapping terms to the documents containing them, the most common indexing approach for web search engines.
An algorithm ranking web pages based on link structure, where a page's importance depends on the number and quality of links pointing to it.
eXtensible Markup Language: a W3C standard from 1998 for representing and exchanging structured data on the web using tagged elements.
A query language for selecting nodes and navigating through elements and attributes in XML documents.
A query language for querying and transforming XML data, supporting complex queries over XML documents.
Resource Description Framework: a data model using triples (subject, predicate, object) to represent information about web resources.
SPARQL Protocol and RDF Query Language: a query language for querying RDF data using pattern matching over triples.
A formal representation of knowledge with concepts, relationships, and rules that provide semantic metadata for data integration.
Web data interlinked using URIs and RDF for machine readability, forming a web of data where datasets are connected through links.
Infrastructure-as-a-Service: cloud service providing computing, networking, and storage resources on-demand. Example: Amazon EC2.
Platform-as-a-Service: cloud service providing development platform with tools and APIs for building applications. Example: Google Apps.
Software-as-a-Service: cloud service providing application software hosted in the cloud. Example: Salesforce CRM.
Database-as-a-Service: cloud service providing managed database systems with automated administration, backup, and scaling.
Adding more servers/nodes to a system to increase capacity. Requires shared-nothing architecture and parallelizable workloads.
Increasing the capacity of a single server by adding more CPU, memory, or storage. Has physical and cost limits.

Front: What is Elasticity in cloud computing?
Back: The ability to dynamically scale resources up or down based on demand, automatically adjusting to workload changes.
A distributed architecture where nodes are independent, share nothing, and communicate only through network messages. Enables linear scalability.
Not Only SQL: databases that trade traditional ACID properties and fixed schemas for scalability, flexibility, and performance. Types include key-value, document, tabular, and graph.
A NoSQL database storing simple (key, value) pairs with operations like put(key, value) and get(key). Examples: DynamoDB, Cassandra.
A NoSQL database storing hierarchical structured documents (JSON or XML) with weak structuring. Examples: MongoDB, CouchDB.
A NoSQL database with multi-valued, timestamped attributes organized in tables with dynamic partitioning. Examples: BigTable, HBase.
A NoSQL database optimized for storing and querying nodes and relationships in graph structures. Examples: Neo4J, OrientDB.
Database systems combining NoSQL scalability and performance with SQL consistency and ACID transactions. Examples: Google F1/Spanner, CockroachDB, VoltDB.
A system providing integrated access to multiple heterogeneous data stores (RDBMS, NoSQL, HDFS) through a unified interface.
A polystore using mediator-wrapper architecture to deal with autonomous data stores, similar to multi-database systems.
A polystore using local interfaces of data stores with a single query language, allowing data movement and query optimization across stores.
A programming model for parallel processing of large datasets with Map phase (transform data) and Reduce phase (aggregate results).
A fast, general-purpose cluster computing framework for big data with in-memory processing, supporting batch and stream processing.
An open-source framework for distributed storage (HDFS) and processing of large datasets using MapReduce programming model.
Hadoop Distributed File System: a distributed file system designed for storing very large files across clusters of commodity hardware.
A repository storing multimodal data in raw format with schema-on-read, supporting multiple workloads (batch, interactive, real-time).

Front: What are the differences between Data Lake and Data Warehouse?
Back: Data Lake: schema-on-read, raw data, flexible, no cleaning. Data Warehouse: schema-on-write, processed data, structured, ETL cleaning.
The end-to-end process for machine learning consisting of Pre-ML (data preparation), In-ML (training), and Post-ML (management).
The phase involving data discovery, data cleaning (missing values, outliers), and data labeling (crowdsourcing, active learning).
The phase involving feature extraction, model selection, and training acceleration using parallelism and specialized hardware.
The phase involving model storage, versioning, deployment, and debugging of trained models.

Front: What is Data Discovery in ML?
Back: Finding sufficient high-quality training data at attribute/tuple level or table level to build ML models.
Removing noise, handling missing values, correcting inconsistencies, and removing outliers from data. Critical for ML as it takes 80% of effort.
Assigning labels to training data for supervised learning, often done through crowdsourcing, active learning, or weak supervision.
Deriving relevant features from raw data through batching, materialization, pruning, or active learning to improve model performance.
Choosing the most appropriate ML model or parameters during training, often involving trying multiple combinations.
Storing trained models efficiently using column-store formats, compression, and indexing techniques.
Tracking model variants, parameters, and metadata to manage iterative training and enable reproducibility.
Putting trained models into production with low latency and high throughput for real-time prediction serving.
Machine learning using labeled training data where the output is known. Includes classification and prediction tasks.
Machine learning without labeled data where patterns and structures are discovered. Includes clustering and association tasks.
ML that characterizes general data properties, discovers patterns, and supports data exploration. User determines important patterns.
ML that performs inference on current data to make predictions about future outcomes or unknown values.
Atomicity (all-or-nothing), Consistency (valid states), Isolation (no interference), Durability (persistent changes). Traditional transaction properties.
Basically Available (system available), Soft state (state may change), Eventual consistency (converges over time). NoSQL alternative to ACID.
Processing large volumes of data in groups at scheduled intervals, with high latency but high throughput. Used in MapReduce.
Processing data continuously as it arrives in real-time with low latency. Used in systems like Apache Flink and Spark Streaming.
Deciding the correct value for a data item when multiple web sources have conflicting information, considering source quality and recency.
Documentation of data's origins, movements, and transformations through its lifecycle, important for trust and debugging.
Google's distributed file system for large-scale data, designed for very large files, mostly read/append workloads, and fault tolerance.
Google's distributed tabular storage system using GFS, with rows having multi-valued timestamped attributes and dynamic partitioning.
A distributed NoSQL key-value store originally from Facebook, providing high availability and linear scalability.
A popular document-oriented NoSQL database using JSON-like documents (BSON) with flexible schema.
A popular graph database management system optimized for storing and querying highly connected data with nodes and relationships.
An open-source tabular store modeled after BigTable, running on HDFS as part of the Hadoop ecosystem.
Uneven distribution of data across partitions causing performance issues, where some nodes have much more data or work than others.
Moving operators between nodes in distributed stream processing to achieve load balancing, fault tolerance, or QoS improvements.
A migration strategy that transfers state partitions to the new host just before they are needed, rather than all at once.

Front: What are the two modes of Lazy Migration?
Back: Latency mode (dynamic state partition with timely scheduling) and Utility mode (essential/unessential attributes with utility functions).

Front: What is a Join Operator in DSP?
Back: An operator combining tuples from multiple streams or tables based on a join condition. Requires windows for stream-stream joins.
An operator computing summary statistics over groups of data. Types include distributive (sum, count), algebraic (avg), and holistic (median).
A non-blocking operator that selects tuples matching specified conditions, implementing selection queries.
The time or count interval defining the boundaries of a window, determining which events belong to that window.
An event arriving after its window has already been computed and emitted, typically handled based on allowed lateness settings.
A signal in stream processing (used in Samza/Kafka Streams) indicating progress of event time, conceptually similar to watermarks.
A mechanism to slow down data sources when the system cannot keep up with the incoming data rate, preventing buffer overflow.
An endpoint operator in stream processing where processed data is output to external systems (databases, files, message queues).
A starting operator in stream processing that produces data into the stream, such as sensors, message queues, or file systems.
An operator that maintains state across multiple events, such as aggregations, joins, or pattern detection operators.
An operator that processes each event independently without maintaining state, such as filters and map transformations.
The system's ability to continue operating correctly despite hardware or software failures.
A procedure for restoring the system to a consistent state after a failure using logs, checkpoints, and replicas.
A marker in the data stream indicating a checkpoint boundary, used in the Chandy-Lamport algorithm to create consistent snapshots.
A replication scheme where all replicas accept both read and write operations, requiring conflict resolution.
Replication where replicas are updated after the primary commits, providing eventual consistency and better performance.
Replication where all replicas are updated before the primary commits, providing strong consistency but higher latency.
A replication scheme where one designated copy (primary) handles all updates, and other copies (secondary) handle reads.
The minimum number of nodes that must agree (vote) for an operation to proceed in a distributed system.
A facility housing computing infrastructure, storage systems, and networking equipment for running applications and storing data.
Distributing data and computation across geographically distant locations for fault tolerance, low latency, and regulatory compliance.
A communication failure that divides a distributed system into isolated groups that cannot communicate with each other.
A situation where network partition causes isolated parts of a distributed system to operate independently, potentially creating inconsistencies.
A failure mode where a node behaves arbitrarily or maliciously, providing incorrect or conflicting information to different nodes.

Front: What is Consensus in distributed systems?
Back: Agreement among distributed nodes on a single data value or decision, essential for consistency and coordination.
A consensus algorithm for distributed systems that ensures agreement even with network failures and node crashes.
A consensus algorithm designed to be more understandable than Paxos while providing the same guarantees.
A mechanism for tracking causality in distributed systems by assigning vector timestamps to events.
An abstract clock for ordering events in a distributed system without relying on physical time synchronization.
A logical clock mechanism assigning timestamps to events for establishing causal ordering in distributed systems.
A consistency model ensuring that causally related operations are seen by all nodes in the same order.
A replication protocol that reads from one replica but writes to all replicas. Provides strong consistency but low availability during failures.
A space-efficient probabilistic data structure for testing set membership, with possible false positives but no false negatives.
A hash technique distributing data evenly across nodes while minimizing reorganization when nodes are added or removed.

Front: What is a DHT (Distributed Hash Table)?
Back: A decentralized distributed system providing key-value lookup functionality across multiple nodes.
A DHT protocol organizing nodes in a ring topology with efficient lookup using finger tables (O(log N) hops).
A communication protocol where nodes periodically exchange information with random neighbors, achieving eventual consistency.
The process of comparing and synchronizing replicas to resolve inconsistencies and achieve convergence.
A tree of cryptographic hashes used for efficient comparison and synchronization of large datasets between replicas.
A database that stores data by columns rather than rows, optimized for analytical queries on large datasets.
A traditional database that stores data by rows, optimized for transactional workloads with many inserts and updates.
Reducing data size for efficient storage and transmission using techniques like dictionary encoding, run-length encoding, or columnar compression.
Dividing data into smaller pieces (partitions or shards) for parallel processing and distributed storage.
Horizontal partitioning of data across multiple databases or servers, where each shard contains a subset of rows.
A partition or node receiving a disproportionate amount of traffic or data, causing performance bottlenecks.
Distributing workload evenly across multiple resources (nodes, processors) to optimize throughput and avoid hot spots.
A DBMS component that determines the most efficient execution plan for queries by evaluating different strategies.
A mathematical model estimating resource usage (CPU, I/O, network) of different query execution plans.
The fraction of tuples that satisfy a predicate condition, used in query optimization to estimate result sizes.
The number of tuples in a relation or result set, used in query optimization for cost estimation.
A data structure approximating the frequency distribution of values in a dataset, used for selectivity estimation.
Selecting a subset of data for analysis or statistics collection, providing approximate answers with reduced processing cost.
A probabilistic data structure providing approximate query answers with bounded error, using sublinear space.
A mathematical function for hierarchical decomposition of signals or data, used for approximate query answering.
A data structure improving the speed of data retrieval operations at the cost of additional storage and maintenance.
A balanced tree data structure commonly used for database indexes, supporting efficient range queries and sorted access.
An index using a hash function for fast equality lookups, providing O(1) average access time.
An index using bitmaps for efficient querying on low-cardinality attributes, common in data warehouses.
An index that determines the physical order of data in a table, with leaf nodes containing actual data rows.

Front: What is a Full Table Scan?
Back: Reading every row in a table sequentially without using indexes, necessary when no suitable index exists.
Using an index to locate relevant rows efficiently, avoiding full table scans when possible.

Front: What is a Nested Loop Join?
Back: A join algorithm using nested loops to compare tuples from two relations, simple but potentially expensive.
A join algorithm using hash tables to match tuples, efficient for equality joins with sufficient memory.
A join algorithm merging sorted inputs, efficient when inputs are already sorted or can be sorted cheaply.
A join algorithm that first sorts both inputs on the join key, then merges them in a single pass.
A distributed join where the smaller relation is sent to all nodes having partitions of the larger relation.
A distributed join where both relations are repartitioned by join key, ensuring matching tuples are co-located.
An optimization moving operations (filters, projections) closer to the data source to reduce data transfer.
Moving filter conditions to the data source to reduce the amount of data transferred and processed.
Selecting only needed columns at the data source, reducing data transfer in columnar storage systems.
The principle of processing data where it is stored to minimize data transfer costs in distributed systems.
The resource cost (time, network bandwidth) of moving data between nodes or between storage and compute.
Executing different operators concurrently on different data, forming a pipeline where output of one feeds another.
Executing the same operation on different data partitions concurrently across multiple processors or nodes.
Executing different independent tasks concurrently, exploiting parallelism between unrelated operations.
Parallelism within the execution of a single operator, partitioning the operator's work across multiple threads/nodes.
Parallelism between different operators in a query plan, executing different stages simultaneously (pipelining).
A programming paradigm based on data dependencies and transformations, where operations execute when input data becomes available.

Front: What is a DAG (Directed Acyclic Graph)?
Back: A graph with directed edges and no cycles, commonly used to represent query execution plans and dependencies.
A sequence of operations for executing a query or job, specifying algorithms, access methods, and data flow.
A low-level execution plan specifying concrete algorithms, access paths, and resource allocation.
A high-level query representation independent of physical implementation details, focused on what to compute rather than how.
Transforming a query into an equivalent but more efficient form using algebraic rules and heuristics.
Storing precomputed view results physically to speed up queries that use the view.
Updating materialized views based on changes to base tables rather than recomputing from scratch.
A sequence of operations treated as a single logical unit of work, satisfying ACID properties.
A transaction property ensuring all-or-nothing execution: either all operations complete or none do.
A transaction property ensuring concurrent transactions don't interfere with each other's execution.
A transaction property ensuring that committed changes persist even after system failures.
An isolation level where concurrent execution of transactions is equivalent to some serial (sequential) order.
An isolation level where each transaction sees a consistent snapshot of the database from the start.
An isolation level preventing dirty reads, where transactions only see committed data.
An isolation level preventing non-repeatable reads, ensuring the same read returns the same result within a transaction.
A concurrency problem where one transaction's update is overwritten by another transaction.
Reading uncommitted data from another transaction that may later be aborted.
Getting different values when reading the same data twice within a transaction due to concurrent updates.
New rows appearing in repeated range queries within a transaction due to concurrent inserts.
A synchronization mechanism preventing concurrent access to a resource, used for concurrency control.
A lock allowing multiple concurrent reads but preventing writes, used for read operations.
A lock preventing all other concurrent access (read or write), used for write operations.
The size of the data item protected by a lock: row-level, page-level, table-level, or database-level.
A situation where two or more transactions wait for each other indefinitely in a circular pattern.
Identifying deadlocks after they occur by constructing wait-for graphs and finding cycles.
Ensuring deadlocks cannot occur through protocol design, such as lock ordering or timestamp-
